name: Ransomware Incident Response Playbook
description: Standardized playbook for ransomware incident response based on NIST SP 800-61

phases.name: Detection & Triage
phases.description: Initial detection and triage of the potential ransomware incident.
phases.objective: Confirm the incident, gather initial indicators, and initiate response.
key_questions: Is this a confirmed ransomware incident?
critical_reminders: Do NOT power off affected systems - volatile evidence will be lost
Do NOT attempt to decrypt files
Do NOT pay the ransom without proper authorization
Document everything from the start
common_mistakes: Powering off systems before memory capture
Attempting to run antivirus without capturing evidence first
forensic_considerations: Preserve system state for memory forensics
Document file extensions of encrypted files

phases.name: Analysis & Scoping
phases.description: Analyze the scope and impact of the ransomware incident.
phases.objective: Determine the full scope of compromise before containment actions.
key_questions: How did the attacker gain initial access?
What is the lateral movement scope?
critical_reminders: Capture volatile evidence (memory) BEFORE network isolation
Check for scheduled tasks and persistence mechanisms
Review authentication logs for compromised accounts

phases.name: Containment
phases.description: Contain the incident to prevent further damage.
phases.objective: Stop the spread while preserving evidence for analysis.
critical_reminders: Network isolation first, then consider shutdown if needed
Keep systems powered on if possible
Block known malicious IPs/domains
Disable compromised accounts immediately
common_mistakes: Shutting down systems before evidence collection
forensic_considerations: Create forensic disk images before remediation
Document all containment actions with timestamps

phases.name: Eradication
phases.description: Remove the threat from the environment.
phases.objective: Eliminate all traces of the ransomware and attacker access.
key_questions: Have all compromised credentials been reset?
Is the initial attack vector closed?
critical_reminders: Identify ALL persistence mechanisms before removal
Reset passwords for ALL potentially compromised accounts
Patch the vulnerability that allowed initial access
common_mistakes: Leaving the initial attack vector open
forensic_considerations: Keep copies of malware samples (secure storage)

phases.name: Recovery
phases.description: Restore systems and return to normal operations.
phases.objective: Safely restore systems with enhanced monitoring for reinfection.
key_questions: Are users aware of the incident?
critical_reminders: Verify backup integrity before restoration
Apply security patches before reconnecting
Enable enhanced monitoring and logging
Restore in phases, not all at once
forensic_considerations: Keep forensic copies separate from recovery

phases.name: Post-Incident Review
phases.description: Review the incident and capture lessons learned.
phases.objective: Document findings, improve processes, and formally close the incident.
key_questions: What could have been detected earlier?
critical_reminders: Complete all documentation while details are fresh
Include all stakeholders in the review
Focus on process improvement, not blame
Update playbooks based on lessons learned
forensic_considerations: Archive all evidence according to retention policy
Prepare materials for potential legal proceedings
